title: 113_s945
content: The Act may be cited as the "Access to Quality Diabetes Education Act of 2013". The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention report a significant increase in diabetes and prediabetes cases in the US. Diabetes affects 8.3% of Americans and 11.3% of American adults, with costs rising to $245 billion in 2012. The cost of diabetes in the US increased by 41% from 2007 to 2012, reaching $174 billion. One in 3 Medicare dollars is spent on diabetes. There were 11.3 million diabetes-related ER visits in 2008. Type 2 diabetes prevalence is rising in children. Diabetes self-management training is crucial for patients. Diabetes self-management training (DSMT) programs help individuals make critical lifestyle changes to manage their diabetes effectively. Certified diabetes educators assist in developing self-management skills to prevent complications and emergency care. DSMT has been proven effective in reducing diabetes risks and complications. Diabetes self-management training (DSMT) programs, led by certified diabetes educators, play a crucial role in helping patients implement treatment plans for better glycemic control and reduced complications. Evidence suggests that proper medical treatment and active self-management can significantly reduce the risk of serious medical complications caused by diabetes. The CDC has recognized the importance of DSMT programs by providing funding to expand the National Diabetes program. The CDC funded the National Diabetes Prevention Program in 2012 to prevent Type 2 diabetes. Medicare could save $2 billion over 10 years by providing quality DSMT. Despite its effectiveness, DSMT is underutilized as a Medicare benefit. Access to certified DSMT programs can improve health outcomes. Public policy goal to improve health outcomes, ensure quality, and reduce diabetes-related costs. SEC. 3. Recognition of certified diabetes educators as authorized providers of Medicare diabetes outpatient self-management training services. The Social Security Act is amended to recognize certified diabetes educators as authorized providers of Medicare diabetes outpatient self-management training services. Certified diabetes educators are defined as individuals licensed or registered by the State as certified diabetes educators or health care professionals. The Social Security Act is amended to recognize certified diabetes educators as authorized providers of Medicare diabetes outpatient self-management training services. Certified diabetes educators are individuals specialized in teaching individuals with diabetes to manage their condition and are certified by a recognized certifying body. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study to identify barriers for Medicare beneficiaries with diabetes in accessing self-management training services. A report on the study will be submitted to Congress within one year. The Director of the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality will develop recommendations on effective outreach methods for educating healthcare providers and the public about diabetes self-management training. A report on these recommendations must be submitted to Congress within one year. The Act applies to items and services provided after a 12-month period from the enactment date.
